platform so what is file based transcoding so I'm sure most of you are
probably aware of what transcoding is so now I spend a whole lot of time on this but essentially I just want to draw the distinction between this and live
streaming so file based on coding is really you have source content in the form of files now this content could be
shot in a studio environment it could be short on a cell phone and everything in
between and you really want to process this content because that's the only way or you can sort of get it into different
versions that will play back on the range of devices and as part of this processing you might want to change the
codec you might want to change resolution you might want to change the frame rate and if it's premium content
you might also want to apply encryption you might want to apply DRM because you want to sort of control access rights to
that piece of content unlike live streaming where you're sort of where you have a real time constraint where you
need to process video exactly at real-time file based transcoding can go
as fast or as slow as the underlying hardware allows and you have control
over how fast you wanted to go by controlling the quality settings the codec settings the resolution and things
are that and historically a lot of
customers have used on-premise solution so we'll look at on trim solutions what the challenges are with that we look at
cloud-based solutions what the challenges are with that but the reason
why file based transport is important and the reason why it needs to be a very conscious decision in terms of what
solution you pick to do your file based transcoding is really driven by these two sort of high-level trends we're
seeing more and more video being produced so unlike in the past where a lot of the video that was produced was
limited to studios with high budgets today anybody and everybody who has
access to a camera and they're generating video at the same time consumer preferences are changing and
there's more and more devices that are being used to view this content so just I read somewhere that based on estimates
about 1.6 billion people all over the world have viewed content on a connected
device so that's very very different from just processing content to deliver to your primary screen which was the TV

content it's really important to be able to get your content onto all of these different devices that consumers are on

but it's also being able to sort of have that flexibility and that agility to be

sort of we invest a lot of money into some of your infrastructure so let's first look
at some of the challenges if you were using on prime or transcoding solutions
so historically like this has been one of the most popular ways of transcoding
content and this requires that the customer basically buy the software or

capex because you had to sort of make that initial upfront payment you had to go set up all of these things you have

of that entire workflow setting that up managing conditional States within the

really easy to sort of set all of that up in a very flexible manner so now I
want to sort of switch gears and talk about the new service that we just announced and with it obvious elemental
media convert our goal was really to make it super easy to build broadcast
grade workflows in the cloud and the way we did that was we basically combined
the encoding expertise the video encoding expertise that elemental had
built up over the years with the distributed systems expertise of AWS and what that really means for customers is
that they have access to professional-grade video features and quality so the same kind of capability
is that elemental server has offered over the years within this service and then it also means that they they don't
really have to manage any software or hardware infrastructure so essentially you're sort of combining sort of the
advantages of on-prem solutions as well as cloud in the sense that you're getting access to a full range of
capabilities and you're getting access to that without having to manage any infrastructure the service automatically
scales in response to variations in your incoming video volume so as a customer
of this service you don't really need to worry about what happens if I suddenly have a spike because what that means for
you in that case is that you're just scaling up the number of job requests you're making to the service and media
convert is responsible for sort of identifying that and then figuring out how it should scale up its fleet and add
new instances to the fleet to go and handle that or spike in video volume and
then finally we do realize that customers are the best people to sort of
figure out how they want to process the content so while we have made it easy to so

as the customer to say these are jobs that are higher priority than another bunch of jobs and you can sort of decide
how you want those jobs should be processed what the order should be and stuff further so let's look at what the
key components are of our media convert so the key thing is the primary unit of
work is a job a job is basically made up of an input one or more inputs really
and then a bunch of settings that define what the outputs that need to be created on a job can also have metadata metadata
is basically key value pairs that you define and those are sort of preserved with the job so if you want to embed
your own sort of intelligence or if you want to enable some tracking within jobs you can do that through metadata now all
of the settings that define a particular output so there's are things like codec or bitrate and resolution and things of
that all of those if you're going to be using the same kind of codec and the same kind of settings you can just save
them as a preset so each preset can basically reference one output and together they basically combine an
output group now you can imagine that for a given job or you're creating more
than one output because if you're doing an HLS stack you're not just doing one one video
output you're basically doing like probably three five ten or depending on your use case and those are and those
will vary based on resolution bitrate and things of that so you can basically define all of that once and save that as
a job template so that you can basically use this template again and again on different inputs so a job template
really sort of saves your input configuration and then it is a collection of presets or settings and
then any of the metadata and the other job configuration that you want to sort of reuse so basically you can create a
job from a job template by combining it with one or more inputs jobs need to be
submitted to queues and queue is really a logical construct for managing the
resources that are available to your account now what I mean by resources is really the of jobs that you can process in parallel
at any given point in time so every job needs to be submitted to a queue and by default every account has access to
about 40 job slots that you can use to process jobs in panel and job so what
that means is if you have just one queue on your account which if the account will have by default let's say you
submit a hundred jobs to that queue 40 of those will start processing immediately the remaining 60 will wait in the queue
manage my media convert and they'll stay there as as long as one of the slots
does not open up so moment likes jobs from that first batch of 40 start to get done there'll be more jobs that will be
picked off the queue and they'll start getting processed so with this sort of a setup you can imagine that if you have a
use case where you have higher priority jobs versus lower priority jobs so for example let's say that you have this
catalog of content that you want to process for a launch that is a month from now and that has like about 10,000
video assets in it but at the same time on an ongoing basis you're also processing files for which you have
essays so you need to turn them around as fast as possible if you just had one queue there are there's a good chance
that all of the files in your library that you don't need processed immediately will probably clogged up all
of your capacity and you definitely don't want that because you want to ensure that any high priority job that
comes and goes to the front of the queue and gets processed and the way to do that is by creating additional queues on
your account and what that does is it splits the resources available to your account across the queues so it's
essentially like creating reserved lanes within your account dedicating resources to it so when you create another queue
on the account each queue can process up to 20 jobs in parallel and then you can submit your low priority jobs to one
queue so only 20 of them will be processed at the time and you'll have 20 slots always free for your high priority
jobs so anytime a new job comes in it'll go straight to the front of the queue and get processed as outputs are being
created they will be placed into s3 so right now a media convert only works
with the content in s3 both in the input and you can only generate outputs and
place in the nest tree and as outputs are being created they
basically go through a different set of states so when you submit a job the first thing that happens is there's a bunch of validation steps that that we
do and then assuming we can they are like we can accept that job it goes into
a submitted state from there it goes into a processing state and from there it can either complete successfully or
it'll fail and at each change in state media convert we'll publish an event to
Amazon Cloud watch so when you're building your workflows you don't need to sort of poll for what the status of
the job is you just need to subscribe to the cloud watch event that's singing that's denoting or signifying a
particular state change and then when you sort of subscribe to that event when the event happens then you can tie that
to another lambda function or you can tie that to a step function and you can sort of drive downstream workflows from it so yeah that's that's essentially
what I'm sort of depicting with using the cloud watch event and then you can use SMS to send yourself like a message
or SMS for email and lambda to run post processing scripts for example that's a pretty common use case that we see so

that you're generating so let's say that you have an hour long piece of content and you're generating five different

outputs which are 30 frames per second AVC codec SP outputs that's the cheapest
that you that has the cheapest rate whereas if you are generating like HEV c with two powers of 4k outputs at 120 fps

was and because it's all in cloud watch you also benefit from the ability to

gets to a value which is not expected so a simple use case especially if you're doing like a a silver less sort of a

how they configure this and they end up using the same s3 bucket for the input and the output and they're just that

have been transported so an easy way to prevent that is to basically look at the metric which is number of jobs
